which is called da B+ and the the
benefits of upgrading to da B+ was it allowed for greater
error checking within the protocol and therefore allowed for better quality audio unfortunately they are not
interoperable as protocols or they you can have a DA be in the D a B+ Station

through how it all work so I'm going to explain why you don't need to know this but I did decide that I was going to cover it for completeness I'm sure any
people who want to know how da B is actually transmitted so the reason that
they decided to implement da be over FM is FM service suffers from a
interference called multipath which is where you get reflections off buildings
and reflections off of other objects and you get interference bit because that
the same signal is received at different times as a result of bouncing off these objects and da B in order to cope with
this interference uses a technique known as orthogonal frequency division
multiplication multiplexing OFDM so essentially what you do
is you have a whole range of carriers in fact just over 1500 carriers which are
all spaced very closely within the band
width and each of those carriers sends a very small data rate it's actually a bit
more complicated than OFDM it's coded OFDM or C OFDM because it includes
forward error correction to to ensure that there's a better quality signal and
the the modulation scheme that's used within this multiplexing approach is
QPSK which is quadrature phase-shift keying and as you can see in that
diagram we've got there it allows for four different symbols 0 0 0 1 1 0 and 1
1 to be represented by four different phases in the way that the the
modulation scheme is set up so the audio
signals that are produced are digitized
because as I said it's a digital broadcast mechanism and multiplex
together with various other data services so although it's primarily sending audio there are lots of other
data services that you can send over da B which is what makes it interesting and
we'll go into the details of the other digital services that you can send later
but essentially they're all multiplexed together and this forward error
protection is applied to it by adding some redundant bits for each consecutive
symbol the bits are divided into those 1536 pairs which are encoded
differentially so based on the previous symbol and then each of those
differentially encoded pairs of bits are used to define the phase of that QPSK
character carrier so like I showed in that the phase diagram those are the bit
pairs and you specify the different phase for each of those within the modulation scheme so that all of that
together forms 1536 carriers in a large kind of wide
bandwidth and that process is repeated again and again symbol Y symbol so just
to explain as a result of that as a result of having lots and lots of different carriers that are all very low
bandwidth you end up with the total bandwidth of just over one megabit we'll make a bet second now I talked about

what are known as common interleaved frames okay so each of those frames is
